channel.title: Desktop Power Supply!
channel.description:
So, you have an old computer its no use, its broken and the power supply is fine! What do you do? You make a handy desktop power supply!
ok well u didnt rely say wut the purpose was bootnecklad` ino bootnecklad` but u didnt say in the thread dumbfk
I'm going to use it to power my breadboard so I don't have to use batterys all the time! [b][I'd rather this stayed in here than in the tutorial section][/b] So the one I had is a small 200W (MAX!) supply, perfect! [u][b]Step one:[/b][/u] [url=http://marc.cleave.me.uk/images/powersupply/DSC00095.JPG]Tools[/url] [url=http://marc.cleave.me.uk/images/powersupply/DSC00080.JPG]Power Supply[/url] So you are going to need a power supply, screw driver, electrical tape and [b]WIRE CUTTERS[/b](I couldn't find mine :() [u][b]Step two:[/b][/u] [url=http://marc.cleave.me.uk/images/powersupply/DSC00081.JPG]unscrewing[/url] [url=http://marc.cleave.me.uk/images/powersupply/DSC00082.JPG]opened[/url] Open it up! [b][u]Step three:[/u][/b] [url=http://marc.cleave.me.uk/images/powersupply/DSC00083.JPG]checking[/url] It would be handy if there was 1 connector coming from the board instead of a it splitting... [u][b]Step four[/b][/u] [url=http://marc.cleave.me.uk/images/powersupply/DSC00084.JPG]cutting[/url] Using WIRE CUTTERS cut the wires (see picture) [b][u]Step five:[/u][/b] [url=http://marc.cleave.me.uk/images/powersupply/DSC00085.JPG]tape[/url] [url=http://marc.cleave.me.uk/images/powersupply/DSC00086.JPG]after[/url] You could use heat shrink to make sure the ends dont short, but I used electrical tape! [b][u]Step six:[/u][/b] [url=http://marc.cleave.me.uk/images/powersupply/DSC00088.JPG]cutting[/url] [url=http://marc.cleave.me.uk/images/powersupply/DSC00089.JPG]after[/url] Cut the ends of the wires to make them neat, snip off any wire coming out. [u][b]Step seven:[/b][/u] [url=http://marc.cleave.me.uk/images/powersupply/DSC00090.JPG]end[/url] Tape the end! Make sure nothing will short. [u][b]Step eight:[/b][/u] [url=http://marc.cleave.me.uk/images/powersupply/DSC00091.JPG]grommet[/url] Fit the wires back into the grommet and put them back. [b][u]Step nine:[/u][/b] [url=http://marc.cleave.me.uk/images/powersupply/DSC00092.JPG]earth tag[/url] Refit that earth tag! screw it back together [b][u]Step ten:[/u][/b] [url=http://marc.cleave.me.uk/images/powersupply/DSC00093.JPG]Finished[/url] DONE! YAY Now then what do I do with this... [img]http://marc.cleave.me.uk/images/powersupply/DSC00094.JPG[/img]
[18:23] bootnecklad, you should incluse in your tutorial that some power supplies won't supply power without the computer being on [18:23] for that you need to cut the green wire and solder it to ground [18:24] didnt think of that...

item.title: Desktop Power Supply!
item.dc:creator: @bootnecklad bootnecklad
item.description:
@bootnecklad wrote:

runescape3dude:

Holy shit, I have an old computer with exactly the same type of cpu/heatsink/fan/mobo/ram. Also, why not just power your breadboard with an old usb cable like I do(Red wire to +ve and black to -ve green and blue/we can just be left out.

What happens if im not near a laptop/computer?

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @peterbjornx peterbjornx
item.description:
@peterbjornx wrote:

wow, that mobo has both AT power supply connector and ATX one

item.title: Desktop Power Supply!
item.dc:creator: @bootnecklad bootnecklad
item.description:
@bootnecklad wrote:

So, you have an old computer its no use, its broken and the power supply is fine! What do you do? You make a handy desktop power supply!

ok well u didnt rely say wut the purpose was bootnecklad` ino bootnecklad` but u didnt say in the thread dumbfk

I’m going to use it to power my breadboard so I don’t have to use batterys all the time!

[I’d rather this stayed in here than in the tutorial section]

So the one I had is a small 200W (MAX!) supply, perfect!

Step one:
Tools
Power Supply
So you are going to need a power supply, screw driver, electrical tape and WIRE CUTTERS(I couldn’t find mine :()

Step two:
unscrewing
opened
Open it up!

Step three:
checking
It would be handy if there was 1 connector coming from the board instead of a it splitting…

Step four
cutting
Using WIRE CUTTERS cut the wires (see picture)

Step five:
tape
after
You could use heat shrink to make sure the ends dont short, but I used electrical tape!

Step six:
cutting
after
Cut the ends of the wires to make them neat, snip off any wire coming out.

Step seven:
end
Tape the end! Make sure nothing will short.

Step eight:
grommet
Fit the wires back into the grommet and put them back.

Step nine:
earth tag
Refit that earth tag! screw it back together

Step ten:
Finished
DONE! YAY

Now then what do I do with this…

DSC00094.JPG1280×960

[18:23] bootnecklad, you should incluse in your tutorial that some power supplies won't supply power without the computer being on [18:23] for that you need to cut the green wire and solder it to ground [18:24] didnt think of that...

Read full topic
